title: Malformed HTML - Invalid type Attribute on Anchor Tag
description: The homepage contains an anchor tag with an invalid attribute: <a class="text" type=text href="xss25">. The 'type' attribute is not a valid attribute for anchor (<a>) tags according to HTML5 specifications. Valid attributes for anchors include href, target, rel, download, hreflang, media, etc., but not 'type'. The 'type' attribute is only valid on elements like button, input, embed, object, script, and style tags. This represents malformed HTML that could cause parsing inconsistencies across different browsers and may indicate incomplete input sanitization or validation in the application code.
impact: While this is primarily a code quality issue, malformed HTML can lead to: 1) Inconsistent rendering across browsers due to different HTML error recovery mechanisms, 2) Potential security issues if browsers handle the malformed HTML differently, 3) Accessibility issues with screen readers that may not properly interpret malformed markup, 4) Future vulnerabilities if browsers implement different parsing strategies for error recovery, 5) SEO degradation due to invalid markup affecting search engine crawlers, 6) Indicates potential code quality issues that could harbor other vulnerabilities.
evidence: The POC successfully identified the malformed HTML on the homepage. Execution output shows: ``` [+] VULNERABLE: Found anchor tag with invalid 'type' attribute [+] Malformed HTML detected: XSS 25 [+] This anchor tag contains an invalid 'type' attribute which is not part of HTML5 specification ``` The anchor tag includes type=text which is invalid according to HTML5 specification. Valid attributes for tags are: href, target, rel, download, hreflang, media, referrerpolicy, etc.
remediation: 1. Remove the invalid 'type' attribute from the anchor tag in the source code 2. Update the HTML to: XSS 25 3. Run an HTML validator (such as W3C HTML Validator or htmlhint) as part of the build process to catch malformed HTML 4. Review other parts of the application for similar HTML validation issues 5. Implement automated tests to ensure HTML compliance with specifications
references: CWE-79 (Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation), HTML5 Specification - Global Attributes, W3C HTML Validator
